confession.devil_appearance: appeared as gentleman, also took forms of dog, cat, and hare
confession.seduction_date: when she was still in service at Haigneviller, gathering wild pears; he visited her for 12 years while in service
confession.seduction_context: Persin offered to buy her a skirt and make her rich when she was gathering wild pears; she refused at first, but yielded when he appeared a second time in form of gentleman
powder_types: yellow powder (given by master to kill husband)
sabbat_activities: feasting - some brought meat, others millet, but she did not because of her poverty

witnesses.name: Estienne Grevel
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor - she begged at his door

testimony.quarrel_subject: He told her not to come begging at their door, but she continued

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: same night after girl gave her bread

testimony.quarrel_subject: His son Claude and Jean Rosselat (as banwards) found her beating water on the river; she said she was lost. They called her witch and spread the word

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: lingered for 2 years or more after the incident
lingered for 2 years or more after the incident

testimony.quarrel_subject: Found by river - said she was looking for 'manchon' she had lost, but they said she had one; she replied she had two and one had fallen in river
Refused her alms

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: later same day, died in 3 days

witnesses.name: Catherine femme Claude Martez
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: landlord - accused rented house from her

testimony.quarrel_subject: Being forced to pay rent of a house
testimony.threat_quote: she would rather risk 50 ecus to have her burned than make reparation

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after being forced to pay rent

testimony.quarrel_subject: Death of cow
She asked him to ferry her across river, but he refused because he was unsure of ability to manage the boat

witnesses.name: Jacques Boisleant
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor - she lived in a room of same house

witnesses.name: Margueritte femme Jacques Boisleant
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor - accused lived in room of same house

testimony.quarrel_subject: After river episode she promised 2 francs to the two men if they would remain silent, but never paid it. Also caught her stealing flax in garden
testimony.threat_quote: en voila desja un des mort qui ne me fera plus de mal (on death of Anthoine, brother of Claude Libault)

testimony.quarrel_subject: In the fields, his wife told her that she had killed her first husband
quarrel (unspecified)

witnesses.name: Claudon femme au maire Pieron George

testimony.quarrel_subject: Being too importunate in demanding alms
quarrel occurred 7 weeks after husband was already ill
Dissatisfied with milk from her, went elsewhere

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 2 days after they told her of the change

witnesses.name: Anne femme Jean Mathieu le viel

testimony.quarrel_subject: Milk provision dispute

witnesses.name: Georgeatte femme Jean Mathieu le jeune

testimony.quarrel_subject: Accused had uttered curses against several neighbors; witness reproached her
testimony.threat_quote: accused called her 'grande ravaderesse de gens'

witnesses.name: George des Boeufs
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: landlord - she had lived in their house

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her children had sometimes called accused witch; witness warned she would complain if any harm came to them
Sometimes spoke roughly to her when she came to door begging
Quarrel over washing as neighbors previous year
Had not invited her to share washtub she prepared
Accused's husband was doing stonework for them, and she was angry because he was drinking wine from tavern. Witness pushed her out of house, and accused knocked off her bonnet
testimony.threat_quote: qu'elle voudroit estre sorciere deux heures pour faire sa volonté - to harm those who called her witch

testimony.quarrel_subject: quarrels (unspecified)
testimony.threat_quote: she often declared she wished she was a witch to do harm to people; told him he would repent after quarrels

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: became ill again and died when accused saw she was blamed as witch

testimony.quarrel_subject: Borrowed 3 francs, repaid after 3 years, but quarreled because Mengeatte wanted some cloth as well as the money

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: 3 weeks later became ill, died 10 weeks later

witnesses.name: Catherine femme Joseph Charpentier
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: neighbor - lived in same house 19 years earlier

testimony.quarrel_subject: During husband's lifetime he sometimes quarreled with her, called her witch, and beat her
Her father refused to sell her something, on advice of witness

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: became all swollen and died within 2 weeks

testimony.quarrel_subject: Mother had quarrel with her coming back from vines
He had threatened to have her burned

timeline.subject: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
timeline.details: Order from substitut du procureur général de Lorraine for depositions to be taken against her and for her arrest, since it has been reported that she is trying to flee

timeline.subject: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
timeline.details: Confrontations - denied all charges of witchcraft, but admitted various quarrels. No reproaches to any witnesses

timeline.subject: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
timeline.details: C.M. Rémy asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - confessed as soon as given thumbscrews

timeline.subject: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

timeline.subject: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
timeline.details: Formal death sentence from court at Lunéville

timeline.subject: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
timeline.details: Execution carried out same day as sentence

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle voudroit estre sorciere deux heures pour faire sa volonté
notable_quotes.english: that she wished she was a witch for two hours to do as she pleased
notable_quotes.context: Told to witness #31, 12 years before trial; when protested, said it was just to harm those who called her witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
notable_quotes.french: en voila desja un des mort qui ne me fera plus de mal
notable_quotes.english: there's already one of the dead who will do me no more harm
notable_quotes.context: Said on death of Anthoine, brother of Claude Libault, who had earlier caught her stealing flax

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
notable_quotes.french: il scait bien maintenant s'il a bien faict, ou non
notable_quotes.english: he knows well now whether he has done well or not
notable_quotes.context: Said when she came to sprinkle holy water on body of Jean Mengeat (witness #31's first husband)

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques
notable_quotes.french: que si son marit alloit en paradis, tout le monde y yroit
notable_quotes.english: that if her husband went to paradise, the whole world would go there

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeatte veuve Grand Jacques (about curé's reprimand)
notable_quotes.french: qu'on n'est pas tousjours bien sage a jecter les parolles en avant
notable_quotes.english: that one is not always very wise in throwing words forward
notable_quotes.context: During confrontations, admitting to reprimand by curé

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie (7-year-old daughter of witness #1)
notable_quotes.french: ma mere, voila la genaxe qui est a la porte
notable_quotes.english: mother, there's the old hag at the door
notable_quotes.context: Child announcing accused's arrival - fell ill same night and died in 4 days

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Carriere (witness #40)
notable_quotes.french: mais qu'elle sembloit estre endurcie aux coups, et qu'ilz ne luy faisoient rien non plus que si on eust touché sur du bois
notable_quotes.english: but that she seemed to be hardened to blows, and that they did nothing to her any more than if one had struck wood
notable_quotes.context: Describing how she was often beaten so hard that anyone else would have been badly hurt

economic_context.details: Accused was destitute, engaged in begging regularly. Had debt dispute with witness #33 (borrowed 3 francs, repaid but quarreled over additional cloth). Rental dispute with witnesses #5 and #6 over being forced to pay rent, after which she was suspected of killing their cow. Accused earned money cleaning houses afflicted with plague. Witness #5 threatened to risk 50 ecus to have her burned rather than make reparation when accused sought legal redress for being called witch and beaten.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Made ill, then illness taken off after learning of his suspicions
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: He told her not to come begging at their door, but she continued

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill same night, stomach became all swollen, died in 4 days with great pain; doctors and apothecary could do nothing; a creature like a scorpion was found in child's bedding after death
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Mother told child to tell accused to come again later, but girl gave her some bread
harms_catalog.method_alleged: creature like a scorpion placed in bedding (apothecary called it 'un sort')

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill and died after lingering for 2 years or more

Found in child's bedding after death; apothecary called it 'un sort'

Witness #30 had not invited accused to share washtub she prepared
Accused's husband was drinking wine from tavern while doing stonework
Accused knocked off witness's bonnet during quarrel
Accused came to sprinkle holy water on body of Jean Mengeat
Witness #33 borrowed 3 francs from accused, repaid after 3 years
Witness #33 gave accused some cloth each year until debt was repaid; then quarreled because Mengeatte wanted cloth as well as money
Anthoine caught accused stealing flax in his garden
Persin offered to buy her a skirt when seducing her
Master gave her yellow powder to kill her husband; put it in his soup
She put yellow powder in her husband's soup to kill him
Money from devil was glass
Some brought meat to sabbat
Others brought millet to sabbat, but she did not because of her poverty
As soon as she was given thumbscrews offered to confess
Claude Blaise beat her with a small stick while calling her witch
Witness #5 said she would rather risk 50 ecus to have her burned than make reparation
After river episode she promised the two men 2 francs if they would remain silent, but never paid

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; residence of accused and most witnesses
Current location of witnesses #5 and #6 (previously at Rehainviller)
Court that issued final judgment; accused claimed to be going to market there when met before dawn; witness #31 was returning from Lunéville
Witnesses #42 and #43 were on way to Remiremont when they met accused 2 hours before dawn
Location of woman (later executed as witch) who advised witness #20's daughter to make pilgrimages for cure
Where accused was in service when first approached by Persin; was sent out to gather wild pears
Location where Claude and Jean Rosselat found her beating water; also where Remy Barthelemin refused to ferry her across; where witnesses heard noise of people; stream where Jean Robert heard noise
Witness #4 was on way to fields when accused admired and touched foal; witness #13's wife told accused in the fields that she had killed her first husband
Witness #39's mother had quarrel with accused coming back from vines
Accused said she thought she was on road to Rehainviller when found beating water on river

economic_hardship_indicators: Accused was destitute and engaged in begging regularly
Accused earned money cleaning houses afflicted with plague
Accused said she did not bring food to sabbat because of her poverty
Third husband described as 'un desbauché gourmant' who spent money she earned
Multiple witnesses describe accused as importunate beggar
religious_calendar_references: Witness #20 threatened to beat accused but did not because it was so close to Easter

officials_named.name: substitut du procureur général de Lorraine

prior_legal_disputes.description: Witness #5 called her witch and beaten her, after which she sought reparation, but abandoned case after witness told her she would rather risk 50 ecus to have her burned than make it
Anthoine caught her stealing flax in his garden

legal_context.redress_outcome: Abandoned case after witness #5 threatened to spend 50 ecus to have her burned rather than make reparation

hearsay_chains.source: his late son Claude and late Jean Rosselat
hearsay_chains.content: that as 'banwards' they had found her beating water on the river
that after episode by river she had promised them 2 francs if they would remain silent, but never paid it
others had remarked on connection between mother's quarrel with accused and subsequent fatal illness, but his mother had said nothing to him

emotional_state_notes: Often cried in the night as if being beaten; said she sometimes dreamed she was being beaten (witness #9)
Was sometimes heard crying strangely in the night; seemed to be still asleep; said in morning she had been dreaming (witness #35)
Seemed to be hardened to blows - could be beaten very hard without being hurt, as if striking wood (witness #40)

third_parties.name: Marie (7-year-old daughter)
third_parties.context: Died in 4 days after giving accused bread at door; stomach became swollen; scorpion-like creature found in bedding

third_parties.name: Claude (son of Didier Liebault)
third_parties.context: Found her beating water on river as banward; called her witch and spread word; fell ill and died after lingering for 2 years or more

third_parties.name: Libaire (first wife of Jacques Boisleant)
third_parties.context: Completely emaciated after 2 year illness; said accused had given her the sickness

third_parties.name: Grand Jacques Masson (third husband)
third_parties.context: Described as 'un desbauché gourmant' who spent money she earned cleaning plague houses and often beat her; accused confessed to killing him with yellow powder in his soup; had called her witch and threatened to have her burned

third_parties.name: Messire Maurin (late curé of Rehainviller)
third_parties.context: Called her witch and told her off; she said she was as innocent as Virgin Mary, and he was very angry

third_parties.name: Anthoine (brother of Claude Libault)
third_parties.context: Caught her stealing flax in his garden; fell ill and died; when he died accused said 'en voila desja un des mort qui ne me fera plus de mal'

third_parties.name: Agnes (daughter of witness #20)
third_parties.context: Became ill within days of accused calling her mother 'grande ravaderesse de gens'; lost use of legs for 6 months; only completely cured after making pilgrimages on advice of woman at Mont

third_parties.name: woman at Mont (later executed as witch)
third_parties.context: Advised witness #20's daughter to make pilgrimages for cure; later executed as witch

third_parties.name: Jean Mengeat (first husband of witness #31)
third_parties.context: Became fatally ill some 3 years after quarrel; when accused came to sprinkle holy water on body said 'il scait bien maintenant s'il a bien faict, ou non'

third_parties.name: Jean Sarmant (first husband of witness #33)
third_parties.context: Became ill 3 weeks after quarrel over debt and cloth, died 10 weeks later, alleging accused had made him ill

third_parties.name: father of witness #38
third_parties.context: Refused to sell her something on advice of witness; became all swollen and died within 2 weeks; accused did not visit during illness or after death

third_parties.name: mother of François Martin (witness #39)
third_parties.context: Became fatally ill after quarrel with accused coming back from vines

third_parties.name: apothecary
third_parties.context: Said scorpion-like creature found in child's bedding was 'un sort'; said with doctors they could do nothing for dying child

third_parties.name: doctors
third_parties.context: Said they could do nothing for dying child who endured great pain

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial with 44 witnesses and extensive testimony. Key features: (1) Accused was destitute beggar with 30-year reputation; (2) Multiple witnesses report she declared she wished to be witch to harm those who called her witch; (3) Notable physical resilience to beatings noted by witness #40; (4) Accused sought legal redress when called witch but abandoned case when threatened; (5) Confessed under torture to killing third husband who beat her and spent her earnings; (6) Earned money cleaning plague houses; (7) Strange nighttime crying reported by two witnesses who lived with her; (8) Meeting accused before dawn on multiple occasions (witnesses #42, #43, #44) used as evidence; (9) Debt dispute over 3 francs and cloth with witness #33; (10) Rental dispute with landlords over forced rent payment; (11) Several witnesses explicitly did NOT suspect her despite reputation; (12) Rapid trial - 19 days from first order to execution; (13) Change de Nancy approved both torture and death sentence without modification; (14) Confessed as soon as thumbscrews applied; (15) Reference to 'banwards' finding her beating water on river - uncertain what 'beating water' means in this context (weather magic?); (16) River/water locations feature prominently in testimony; (17) Trial shows pattern of quarrels over alms/begging being refused, followed by harms to animals or family members. Economic desperation clearly visible throughout testimony.
